channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: A Competition for Converts in Arunachal Pradesh
item.description: As indigenous peoplein the northeastern state convert to Christianity, society is increasingly being drawn along religious rather than tribal lines.
item.dc:creator: By MAX BEARAK
item.media:description: Women in Itanagar, Arunachal Pradesh selling firewood in front of a wall bearing posters advertising Indigenous Faith Day celebrations in Dec., 2013.

item.title: United Nations: Plea for Funds to Aid Millions in Africa’s Sahel Region
item.description: The United Nations appealed on Monday for more than $2 billion to feed and care for 20 million people across Africa’s Sahel belt.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Yemen: Western Employee of Oil Company Kidnapped
item.description: Gunmen on Monday kidnapped a European oil employee in Sana, the capital, hours after the city was rocked by overnight explosions, the second abduction of a Westerner in four days.
item.dc:creator: By AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: The Lede: Both Sides Declare P.R. Victory in Skirmish Over SodaStream Super Bowl Ad
item.description: Both supporters and critics of Israel’s occupation of the West Bank declared victory after Scarlett Johansson’s Super Bowl ad for SodaStream was broadcast Sunday night.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Potent Pro-Israel Group Finds Its Momentum Blunted
item.description: A Senate bill to impose new sanctions on Iran, a top priority for the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, has stalled after stiff resistance from President Obama.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama addressing Aipac in 2012. The pro-Israel group and Mr. Obama are at odds over its push for new Iran sanctions.

item.title: Jean Babilée Dies at 90; Ballet’s Acrobatic Star
item.description: Mr. Babilée was a French ballet star and choreographer who rejected conventions in dance and life.
item.category: Le Jeune Homme et la Mort (Movie)
item.dc:creator: By ANNA KISSELGOFF
item.media:description: Jean Babilée and Nathalie Philippart performing Roland Petit’s “Le Jeune Homme et la Mort” in Paris in 1946.

item.title: The Lede: Leaked Video Shows Arrest of Al Jazeera Journalists in Egypt, Set to Hollywood Soundtrack
item.description: Al Jazeera condemned what it described as “an attempt to demonize” two of its reporters, Peter Greste and Mohamed Fahmy, with the release of video recorded during their arrest in December in Cairo.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Dispute Over Italian Marines Prompts Bickering in Indian Court, but No Resolution
item.description: India’s Supreme Court refused to resolve a dispute with Italy over the prosecution of two Italian marines accused of killing two Indian fishermen in 2012.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Video of Journalists’ Arrest in Egypt Seen as Threat to Media
item.description: Government critics called a leaked video of two journalists being arrested in a Cairo hotel room in December an attempt to intimidate opponents of the military-backed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Jiangmen Journal: A Long Goodbye for a Lost Railroad
item.description: Only a few historical markers and dim memories remain of a railroad built by a Chinese man who made his fortune in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Alan Chin for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Doushan, China, a statue of Chen Yixi and a locomotive mark the southern terminus of the former Xinning Railway.

item.title: Karzai Arranged Secret Contacts With the Taliban
item.description: Peace talks with the Taliban could explain why the Afghan president has held up a security deal, straining his relationship with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan has refused to sign a deal he brokered for security there after Western troops leave.

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: Decree Lays Out Penalties for Fighting Abroad
item.description: King Abdullah issued a royal decree that punishes citizens who fight in conflicts outside the kingdom, with prison sentences ranging from three years to 20.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Knox Judge Faces Inquiry
item.description: Italy’s justice minister announced an investigation into comments made to the Italian news media by the judge who read the guilty verdicts against Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: French Comic Barred
item.description: The controversial French comedian Dieudonné M’Bala M’Bala has been barred from entering Britain because of his extreme views, the Home Office said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: 3 Jailed in Anti-Gay Case
item.description: A court in Russia’s Far East on Monday found three men guilty of murdering a man in an attack that prosecutors said was motivated by homophobia.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK REEVELL

item.title: Presidential Elections in El Salvador and Costa Rica Are Headed for Runoffs
item.description: Top contenders in both nations failed to get enough votes on Sunday to win outright, in contests that tested the power of incumbent parties.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Trade Issue Goes Untouched as Obama and Reid Meet
item.description: President Obama met with Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, but made no effort to seek additional authority to negotiate trade deals.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ASHLEY PARKER
item.media:description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, opposes granting the president additional authority to negotiate trade deals.

item.title: Catering to the Chinese Shopper’s Grand Tour
item.description: Purveyors of luxury brands are stepping up their efforts to sell to Chinese tourists in Europe, where many prefer to spend their money.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Agnes Dherbeys for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese tourists outside the Galeries Lafayette department store in Paris last month.

item.title: Iran Giving Food Away to Millions for Relief
item.description: The authorities began the initiative, which drew long lines, both to help those with low incomes and to try to lower inflation on food prices, local news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Australian Catch-and-Kill Shark Policy, Meant to Reassure, Horrifies Some
item.description: Citing swimmer deaths, Western Australia State has started a catch-and-kill policy for larger sharks, but environmentalists say it will have a deleterious effect on the ecosystem.
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:credit: Bohdan Warchomij for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered at Cottesloe Beach in Perth, Australia to protest the catch-and-kill shark policy on Saturday.

item.title: Al Qaeda Breaks With Jihadist Group in Syria Involved in Rebel Infighting
item.description: The Qaeda leadership said it was no longer connected to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, which has asserted an increasingly important role in the Syrian conflict.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China to Ramp Up Military Spending
item.description: China will spend $148 billion on its military this year, up from $139.2 billion in 2013, according to a new report.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Chinese sailors stand at attention on the deck of the aircraft carrier Liaoning in the northeastern port of Dalian.

item.title: An Olympian Snow Endeavor in Sochi
item.description: To dress Alpine venues of the Sochi Games in white has required the help of science, a lot of machines and a little luck.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN
item.media:description: Snow being made at Rosa Khutor, the Alpine venue for the Winter Olympics. More than 400 machines were installed there.

item.title: Former BBC Director Apologizes for Failure of Digital Project
item.description: Mark Thompson, now president and chief executive of The New York Times Company, testified that he had never “knowingly misled” Parliament over the project’s progress.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Two Families Battered by a Typhoon
item.description: The Picas, who struggled to keep a baby born during Typhoon Haiyan alive, are piecing their lives back together in Tacloban, while the Siozans, who lost their patriarch from an infection, have left.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Catholic priest blesses the remains of Jesus Siozon Sr., a 93-year-old who would become possibly the last person in Tacloban to die from the effects of the typhoon.
